question: Yeah, that's the grand old bird. Right now I just wish the son-of-a- bitch could fly. Uh huh. Win what? Terrific... ...that's just what I needed...one more chance to lose. No!...God, don't shoot! Korea? No shit, so was my old man... Aaaaaaaargh! Thanks. I thought you didn't see me. You want me to drive? No offense...thought you might...
answer: All right, people. Quiet! We're losing the sun! This is a take! You're welcome to watch, but please, no flashbulbs. They'll spoil the shot.

question: Medic! Get the medics! 41A A WOMAN sags into a faint. A small child in the crowd is crying and clutching Cameron's leg.
answer: Cut! I said CUT! That's a print.

question: Hey! Hey, give me your hand! Don't be afraid! You're gonna be okay. My God! You're...I know you...that girl from TV...the actress. Nina...
answer: ...Franklin.

question: My God!...Why the hell...?
answer: ...Makeup test...it's for the film...

question: They gotta be crazy to cover that face.
answer: I'm only old at the end of the story. No, don't do that. Rescue me!

question: In three feet of water?
answer: Oh come on, please. I always wanted someone to rescue me from something...

question: Oh come on, please. I always wanted someone to rescue me from something...
answer: Nina! You damned near scared me to death!

question: Oh hell, it's all ruined now and I wanted you to see the makeup, Eli. Where were you?...I even got Raymond's autograph and he didn't know...You'd have been proud...
answer: Get her into a tub, then bed...and I want to see her in makeup and costume again before dinner.

question: Hey! Thank you! That was really gallant...rescuing an old lady!
answer: Wait a second! I want to thank you, too!

question: Wait a second! I want to thank you, too!
answer: Yeah, I also smoke too much.

question: You and Burt on the bridge...how about telling me what happened?
answer: I don't know. He must've gone crazy. He tried to run me down.

question: Oh?...Why would he do that?
answer: ...I didn't ask him why! All I know is he was comin' at me very fast. 'You want to get home for Thanksgiving, you better figure the guy comin' at you is tryin' to kill you'...That's one thing I learned from the gooks.

question: Gooks?...That has a nostalgic ring... You guys really used to call them gooks? I thought that was just Time Magazine.
answer: That was 'Nam. What should I call 'em, WOPS? Nobody'd known what I was talkin' about.

question: Speaking of jail...would you get upset if I asked how many cops were after you?
answer: What are ya talkin' about?

question: Your I.D. bracelet...the look on your face...the way you ran from the bridge... I...don't suppose you want to tell me what you did.
answer: No...I don't.

question: ...Could I try categories? Ever done any stunt work?
answer: What?

question: How'd you like to be a stunt man? You look like you're in pretty good shape, fast on your feet. You could do it. Besides, You're not gonna have much choice. Now, don't get hasty. And, remember your ass, it's just like mine... maybe I can save them both.
answer: You said you'd be gone four days ago, before the season started. You lie, break promises... Cross, I've gone out of my way, but this time...

question: Jake, it's been a rotten morning. You're hot and tired. Let's go in, have us a drink and find out what's eating you.
answer: Don't treat me like these other morons! You know goddamn well what's eating me is that Duesenberg on the bottom of the river with the dead man in it! I mean, that is a goddamn public bridge and a public river! You go there without permits, without any precautions and get a man killed!

question: Jake...
answer: No more bullshit explanations. Just go...before I figure out how to hang you with a manslaughter charge!

question: He didn't get out. Our divers got him out...and brought him back in the chopper. You did that very well.
answer: I didn't get a chance to say a word. I just listened.

question: There are only a few actors in the world who have mastered that art. Anyway, it was a good audition. You landed the part.
answer: How? What about the crew? They going to look at me and say, 'Hi, Burt?'

question: Unless you prefer, 'Hi, Elizabeth.' Don't worry about my crew, they'll call you anything I want 'em to. Look, I'm not being callous. Burt is a fucking tragedy, but there's nothing in the world I can do about it...I've gotta have this location for three more days...and you need a place to hide.
answer: By tomorrow the local cops'll know what I look like. I can't hang around.

question: Why not?
answer: You're too good looking. His idea of a perfect stunt double is two- hundreds pounds of hamburger in a red wig...

question: What's she like? I've seen her on
answer: At selling douche powder, she's fabulous; dog food?...I'm not sure she's sincere.

question: What are you sore about?
answer: I'm not sore. Isn't that what you wanted to know? ...Or did you mean, what's the real Nina Franklin like--without the greasepaint and tinsel... ...You mean, what's she like -- underneath? What do those say about the girl who wears them? Shy? Delicate? Sensitive? Still wet...very wet.

question: You sure he can breathe? Where's Raymond? Remember, you just crashed...you were wandering the beach behind the German lines looking for a place to hide when you saw the explosion. You're stunned by the carnage. That bomb was dropped by a guy in your squadron. Okay? Roll the film.
answer: Gotcha that time! Didn't we?

question: Yeah, you got me another half-hour behind.
answer: Thought the chief could use a little cheering up today.

question: ...So you heard the news about Burt...
answer: Any more word?

question: Afraid not...there's no picture ever made that's worth it.
answer: I'll never understand why these guys do it -- take the chances.

question: Don't know. Trying to beat the system, I guess...we all know that some day we're gonna die of nothing more important than wrinkles...and that makes us so scared and crazy, we'll do anything. Go off bridges...fight windmills...wars... anything. That's what our film's about -- or didn't you know? Hey, Burt, come over here.
answer: My new cock and balls?

question: If I stamp "rush" on my mare's ass, she'll still take eleven months to foal. Call the lab and find out when! I lost a man today. I wanna see that footage and find out why. Done any stunt work?
answer: Not really.

question: Not really? You have or you haven't?
answer: I got out of Vietnam in one piece. Let me tell you that wasn't a bad stunt.

question: That's ancient history.
answer: Seems like yesterday.

question: Could you jump from that tower to the that roof?
answer: Once, to save my ass, I jumped out of a banana tree into an oxcart full of buffalo shit. Does that count?

question: We'll see. Put these on.
answer: Where do they go?

question: Under the pants. I want you to jump from here...to there.
answer: Okie-dokie.

question: Very good. Except you're dead!! Your brains are scattered all over the goddamn pavement. You landed on the edge and fell backwards four stories. Where do we send the body?
answer: Don't bury me yet.

question: You're still dead! You fell over the other side of the building. You wanna try it right, once? You should land in a tuck-and-roll.
answer: Show me, sergeant. Very fancy. Okay?

question: Better.
answer: My speciality is Hopscotch.

question: And Burt's specialty was drowning. You know one goddamn daredevil on this picture was enough! What the hell was Eli thinking, giving me a smart-ass, cocky, amateur kid when I need a stunt man! It's a little different running across that roof when they're pumping tracer bullets over your head.
answer: I was running for twenty-six months with guys shooting at me...not over my head...at my head and I'm alive. I knew daredevils. I got nothing against them...it's just they're all dead. So ease off and give me a chance... Hey, were you putting me on?

question: Me? I wouldn't know how to do that. Can you imaging Eli doing a World War I picture without horses? Do you know the gags I could do with four runaway horses pulling a caisson? ...Next time hit me higher.
answer: What's Eli got against horses? I love horses.

question: Don't butter me up. We'll draw a sight line for you to follow down the roof here, while you're rolling. Now there's nothing very difficult. But this is where you gotta think. Your mind can't be on snatch. It's gotta be on grabbing that gutter.
answer: Or my brains are all over the pavement again, right?

question: You know a good falling horse makes more money in four minutes than a bank president does in a year?
answer: Picture's not over. Maybe you'll still get your chance.

question: Naw, all they care about is story. Now here's where the scuffle ends. When the pipe breaks loose, you fall and hit that awning. Then Eli yells "cut" and old Raymond takes your place for the close-ups and the glory. That's where the German soldiers catch him and throw him in the nuthouse. They're shootin' that scene downstairs now.
answer: That's supposed to hold me? Probably doesn't hold rain.

question: It's not a real awning, it's a catcher.
answer: Yeah, how much?

question: You're stealing candy with this gag. You get six hundred bucks. ...Christ! Watch it, will ya? What did you think a stunt man is? He's a professional. If the camera jams, that's another six hundred and if Eli says "try it again," six hundred more.
answer: Yahooo! Six-fucking-hundred-bucks!!

question: ...Save it, everybody. ...Never mind. I didn't like it anyway.
answer: What's wrong?

question: The scene's wrong. Call a break.
answer: Eli, it played like a dream. My God, it was Marat-Sade.

question: It played like shit!
answer: Well, who was that on the phone in the middle of the night when you first read it, raving about the magical madhouse scene, the upstairs maid? What do you wanna do, Eli?... They're all waiting. Being childish isn't going to help your movie...You know, there's nothing wrong with the story. The real problem is since I wrote this thing two years ago, you've had Watergate, the energy crisis, Women's Lib, the economy is down the tubes...You want to talk about burning issues?...There's arsenic in the glue on the back of food stamps! That's why you don't like the "madhouse scene." Your goddamn war story has lost its relevance.

question: Don't be negative, Sam. We can start a new one in time for the preview.
answer: Cut it out, will ya? Two years ago you were all charged up to make a great big anti-war statement and they wouldn't let you. Now they let you, but you haven't got a war. What you've got is egg on your face because Vietnam's long gone and it's too late!

question: Our picture's not about fighting wars...
answer: Oh?

question: ...It's about fighting windmills. War isn't the disease...It's only one of the symptoms.
answer: What's the disease?

question: That's the big question, Sam. Name the disease and you've licked the screenplay. Ask him. 'Cause he knows what the film is about. Right Lucky? Tell 'em...How'd you like Vietnam?
answer: How'd you like bubonic plague?

question: You drafted?
answer: No.

question: See, Sam? Here's another one who hates war...but he enlisted. You fought in Vietnam for two years? ...I mean actually were out there killing people...
answer: ...Hey, I didn't kill that many people...

question: Don't be modest, Lucky. Everybody digs a little violence...What was that you said on the beach?
answer: About what?

question: About getting home for Thanksgiving?
answer: ...that you better figure the guy coming at you is trying to kill you...?

question: Don't go away, Burt. I want you.
answer: Jake! Long time, no see. You taken care of my problem with the beach?

question: I'm not talking to you. I understand you got that film out of the Duesenberg...
answer: It's at the lab, Jake.

question: I'm talking to this gentleman. We want to see it.
answer: Tell the Chief it's our pleasure. Soon as it gets back...but ask him why.

question: Tell the Chief that Burt was so busy being brilliant, he wouldn't have noticed Jesus Christ walking on the water. Hey, Burt! You got it upside down. The eyes go on top.
answer: A couple of telephone linemen say they saw him headed this way.

question: Looks like a nice clean-cut kid.
answer: I know about fifty guys who don't think so.

question: What'd he do?
answer: The minute that film gets here you give me a call.

question: We should have waited, it wouldn't have been an hour. 74A They've entered the hotel. Cameron continues to the bottom of the stairs, hesitates, looking back at Nina.
answer: Hi.

question: Yes. It does look pretty high. Are you worried about tomorrow?
answer: Not much. I guess if there were any real danger, Eli wouldn't let me do it, would he?

question: No. I'm sure it's safe.
answer: Good. Then you jump.

question: Okay.
answer: Well, come on.

question: What, right now? Wait, I'm afraid of heights! What if I freeze up?
answer: Don't worry, I'll give you a push. Isn't that what a pal's for?

question: Oh, my God! It's terrifying! You can't jump from this...you'll get killed! It's crazy!...
answer: ...It's not that bad. It looks worse at night... Chuck says it's like robbing a candy store.

question: Now stop that! ...I'm going back.
answer: ...What's wrong?

question: It's just dumb...to strut around trying to talk brave...
answer: Not really.

question: Yes. You are...You're trembling.
answer: So are you...and you're not even gonna jump.

question: Oh, for Christ's sake...
answer: There once was a maiden fair, smooching a guy with red hair...

question: Eli, get away with that thing!
answer: ...Could it be Raymond who's turning this dame on? ...Or his double, young Lucky Pierre?

question: It's gotten to the point where I have to look under the stopper of the bathtub when I take a shower to make sure I've got some privacy! Thank you one and all and good night!
answer: Step right in, folks...the "Killer Crane" ride of the century.

question: Step right in, folks...the "Killer Crane" ride of the century.
answer: Thanks, I'll walk.

question: Ah, youth. Six hours in town and caught with the leading lady. Not bad. Shouldn't be so upset.
answer: Okay to be upset about what happened in the dining room? Why'd you promise to show that cop the film? He'll recognize me.

question: Is this my present?
answer: No, your present is a piece of good advice.

question: Keep it.
answer: You've got that look again. That gleam of the sprinter about to set a record for the 50-yard dash. Is that why all those cops are chasing you? What are you, some kind of sex freak running across America with your fly open? Is that why they're after you?

question: You're close. What's your advice?
answer: Button your fly and be at the airport on Sunday at three o'clock with the rest of the crew. Climb aboard our chartered 707 and fly away with us to where the setting sun bleeds into a million swimming pools a man can hide in. You do swim as well as run?

question: I'll swim like a fish. You really mean it? Why are you trying to save my ass?
answer: ...Because you're as crazy as the guy I'm doing the picture about. ...Besides, I've fallen madly in love with the dark side of your nature.

question: Why didn't you tell me about the awning? I could have been killed.
answer: No chance. You were in your mother's arms from the time you hit the sugarglass skylight. Those stunt men you fell on would have got you out of anything.

question: Stunt men?
answer: The one with the tits and the other guy.

question: Why didn't you tell me? Afraid I'd chicken out?
answer: Eli likes some things spontaneous. Makes 'em more believable. You're okay. Whaddya want?

question: God knows, Sam. Maybe...because you get the feeling that the enemy might just be some poor horny slob like you, lookin' for the nearest whorehouse. How about that, Lucky? When that stunt man's boob hit you in the mouth, was it just another boob...or did it taste like kraut?
answer: It tasted lousy. But what do I know? You try it, Eli. You're the expert in bad taste.

question: Uh-oh, sounds like the soldier's got his feelings hurt.
answer: Naw, naw. I just don't know about Germans. Where I was we only raped gooks.

question: Oh, is that why the cops are after you? ...After all this time?
answer: Damn! You finally guessed it!

question: ...Goddamn little prudish bastard!
answer: No more than you and me...it's the human condition. We just hide it better.

question: ...Are you kidding?...If That guy in the rowboat was a Marine sticking a bayonet in her instead of a cock, that uptight son-of-a-bitch would have saluted. Fucking Fascist. What are you laughing at?
answer: It's just...that girl in the rowboat, she looks exactly like your daughter, Jennifer.

question: Goddamn you, Eli. That's not funny! Son of a bitch.
answer: See what I mean? Old Victoria's still got us all by the balls. God save the queen!...Only difference is, we like to make movies about it. Harvey, dailies at six o'clock tomorrow morning. We're shooting at seven. All right now, let's put a little bit of class into this production!

question: How they get the film developed so fast? What's the matter?
answer: Don't let the fact that Eli treats you as an equal go to your head. You're not!

question: Thanks.
answer: I'm sorry, Eli.

question: But he can say anything and that's okay...
answer: ...That's right...

question: ...That's great...
answer: ...What goes on in that dim little head of yours? How dare you open your mouth to him like that? Have you the vaguest idea what he's trying to say to people with this film?!...That man is the most dedicated, kindest...!

question: It's so awful, it's beautiful. Wish I could use it.
answer: That's all we'd need.

question: We goddamn well need something, Sam. Something better than we got...
answer: Better? How better?

question: Wilder, crazier.
answer: Dropping a dead man's boots over his own airfield, out of chivalry... that's not crazy enough for you?!

question: They did it in "Wings." Even the dummy was bored. You can't shake your finger at 'em, Sam. If you've got something to say, you better slip it in while they're laughing and crying and jacking off over the sex and violence. He should do something...outrageous!
answer: Like what?

question: Something to catch the stink of madness behind all that good clean fun. Why the hell did we pick World War I in the first place?...The ultimate romantic insanity!
answer: Like what?!

question: Like...I don't know what! What would Lucky do if he were on the wing of that plane? Picture that because it would be a hell of a lot realer than that flapping dummy.
answer: Is that what you're after, reality? I thought you wanted something outrageous!

question: Great! That's what we'll do.
answer: Eli...

question: All right, not a jig...a Charleston...
answer: A Charleston?

question: ...On the wing of the airplane!
answer: ...That's ridiculous.

question: You're damn right...
answer: The Charleston is silly...They won't believe it.

question: I'll do it so they'll believe it!
answer: You'll get a laugh, Eli.

question: Only when I want them to laugh!... Right, Lucky?
answer: Fan-fucking-tastic. Whaddya been feeding that soldier-boy...brave pills?

question: It's not what he's eating...it's what's eating him...that makes it sort of interesting. Okay, drop the package. How is it?
answer: Su-fucking-perlative.

question: That's twice for me today. Now. And when I watched you do the stunt. I have to study my scene for tomorrow. The Old Lady at the cemetery. It's brutal. I set the clock in case we dozed off.
answer: How come they cast you as an old lady?

question: I start out as a young girl hiding this American flyer. I'm Austrian... Will ya turn off the clock? Anyway, his patriotism is stronger than his love and he leaves me with another little patriot in my belly.
answer: Why can't I double for both of you? I could use the money and I don't look half bad.

question: Honey, you'll ruin it. Take it off. The clock's electric. It'll ring forever.
answer: Eli might really go for that, the big soldier as a little old lady.

question: What's wrong?
answer: Everything's beautiful.

question: What are you doing?
answer: We've got to consider Eli. If you don't study the scene, he'll be mad...then you'll get mad...and I'll get shot out of a cannon.

question: Did you fall on your head today?
answer: I want it to ring.

question: Why?
answer: For me, that's why. That's Eli yelling for you to work on your scene and us saying, "Up yours, Eli," and I like that.

question: Do you want to leave?
answer: I want to make love to you while Eli is screaming his head off.

question: I can't make love with the clock ringing.
answer: Betcha can. You tell 'em, Eli.

question: Betcha can. You tell 'em, Eli.
answer: Crazy bastard! There was no way it could go wrong...unless he just went ape. The harness is okay...the roof is holding...it all seems fine.

question: But look at him struggle...
answer: ...Badly. Eli wouldn't use a foot of it...poor slob died for nothin'.

question: That crack...in the windshield...
answer: Shit. That's where it stops. That fuckin' Henry...got spooked and took his finger off the remote button.

question: Is this how the story was supposed to end, with the flyer dying in the water?
answer: Sure as shit ended that way for Burt, didn't it?

question: The graveyard's over here... ...Her car's parked here. ...Lots of these little graveyards along the roadside...most of the stones are unmarked... You're tired...you're broke...all things which meant so much are gone. What's left is a single memory... that brief bright love. ...You spent your month's pension in hiring the car. You just can't look for his grave any longer...so you pick one...any one. You kneel... then lay the flowers down. What have we got for her? No...something she picked herself... wildflowers or something.
answer: Eli. An idea, maybe. Instead of flowers, what if she brought him the things of their life together...of their sexuality...like her nightgown, her underclothes... 'Course they'd be rags by now, but let me show you this...

question: Sam, you'll get a belly laugh.
answer: What do you mean? It'll break their hearts!

question: Why do I lie? I couldn't wait either. I think both of us are bears. Go, young maiden, you'll be late for your piano lesson.
answer: Signora...signora...

question: I'm almost finished.
answer: Signora. This desecration... some flowers perhaps...would be permitted.

question: But, we want these.
answer: Please, signora. It's not right. The grave is unmarked.

question: Ask the driver how many graves we visited today. I could have chosen five hours ago. I came here and my soul said, "Oh yes." I know that is hard to believe...
answer: Anything is possible, signora. Now, you must permit me to escort you to your car.

question: As soon as I am gone, you will take everything away.
answer: No...

question: Change of plans. We're making the stunt a fire gag. When you come out of the barn, you're in flames...wanna try it. Look, don't do it if you don't wanna...
answer: What does Eli say?

question: You know Eli... "Tell the soldier it's an extra hundred bucks and he'll do it without the asbestos." Whaddya say?
answer: Tell Eli to do it.

question: Hey, what the hell is wrong with you?
answer: I'm tired of being somebody's goddamn clown!

question: Young man, taking my life in my hands, I must inform you that you are an asshole. Being a devout masochist, it follows that I'm Eli's best friend. I know quite a lot about him and Nina.
answer: You and the entire crew, buddy.

question: He met her three years ago. Two lonely people rattling around New York. A brutal winter. Eli's marriage had just broken up...
answer: ...All she had to do was tell me! You telling me he banged her once three years ago? Yeah... So how's the new ending coming?

question: I got fourteen versions. Take your pick. What are you doing in there?
answer: ...Fourteen gory ways to die?

question: Thirteen. In one version he lives...turns the girl in, opens a gay bar in Berlin, gains fifty pounds and changes his name to Goering... ...Please, anything but the sweaters. You'll stretch the hell out of the sleeves.
answer: I was sort of invited to a birthday party and I can't seem to find it...and this seems to be a birthday party... She's really worth finding, ma'am. She's a very rare mineral. This morning she was acting about ninety, but she might be lying a year or two.

question: I was sort of invited to a birthday party and I can't seem to find it...and this seems to be a birthday party... She's really worth finding, ma'am. She's a very rare mineral. This morning she was acting about ninety, but she might be lying a year or two.
answer: I'm sorry it got so late...that damn five o'clock makeup call...I feel as bad as you do...

question: In the same place I do?
answer: Will you take a raincheck? ...A permanent one?

question: A season pass.
answer: Good night.

question: Lucky...hey Lucky, come over here! Guess who tole 'em to take their job and stuff it?
answer: Ya quittin'?

question: Fuckin' A. Gettin' out tonight. But not without splittin' a Schlitz with the one guy, 'cept me, who wouldn't take shit from that screwball. Change is for you, except that. That's a very special dime. Know what this is? Ask me!
answer: It's a dime...am I close?

question: It's Eli Cross' ass. People think 'cause you're easygoin' they can walk all over you. Bull-shit...I'm blowin' the whistle with this dime in that phone...killin' a man and hiding it from the police...are you kiddin'...? Who is he think he is? What the hell you doin'? Do whatever you wanna do, but I better do it with ya! You'll need help 'cause that goddamn looney is dangerous.
answer: Not to me, he ain't. I'm going to the cops. You gotta earn your living in pictures, but I don't give a shit. He can't hurt me.

question: Don't be too sure. Damned psycho nearly strangled me! Don't believe me? Wanna see marks...? ...Lucky to be alive!
answer: Henry, what are you talking about? I watched that whole thing today, he didn't even touch you.

question: Not today. When Burt went into the water. I could tell from up there in the chopper something' was wrong. So, I stopped shootin' and that crazy man gets me by the throat and starts screamin' to roll the film...I mean that guy's down there dying and he's screamin', "Keep shooting! Keep shooting!" Then, he starts fighting me for the switch and it falls down...like a crazy house up there, with him thrashin' on the floor...He didn't care about Burt. All he cared about was to get that man dyin' on film! Sickest thing I ever seen! I better grab that cab. You tell 'em everything...don't mince words...
answer: Nina...your crazy Eli...

question: Nina...your crazy Eli...
answer: Get out of here! Get out!!! I'll have you thrown out!

question: Is there anybody in this whole company you haven't screwed? My girl gave me her key!
answer: I am not your girl! I am that man's girl! That man and I have been lovers for six months! I've known you two days!

question: Then gee, ma'am, I sure hope you didn't tell him about all that ballin' last night.
answer: Don't you dare be clever with me! He came scratching at the door tonight like a beaten dog, begging me to say that you were some twenty- four hour nonsense. ...and I had to tell him I thought I was falling in love with...

question: You couldn'a said that with your clothes on?!
answer: Goddamn you! The wounded stud! He is entitled to some dignity! To lose his "pure and faithful lover" without the new boy barging in! Where do you suppose he is now?

question: Did ya look in the laundry hamper?
answer: GET OUT! Get the HELL OUT!!

question: I don't have any rights? I don't have the right to be pissed off...?
answer: You don't have the right to breathe! I knew him before I met you! Do you understand that?! Before I met you!! If we were frightened, we woke each other in the dark...we slept in each other's arms...

question: The word is "fuck!"
answer: All right, the word is fuck! You narrow, insensitive, stupid...!

question: Don't. Don't push me. I don't know this freaky world you live in, but I know that there still must be a couple of places where people somehow believe in...
answer: Believe in what? You're blushing. A place where what? Don't get embarrassed at this late date!

question: ...A place where a guy has a right to blow his top if he finds his lover screwing...
answer: Raymond's lover! Raymond's lover! Say it! Raymond's lover! I'll have it typed up and notarized...! Raymond's lover! And you will sign where it says, agreed! You won't turn me into some rotten whore because your papa once told that a woman is a certain way "and that's how it's gonna be 'til Gabriel blows his horn..."

question: Okay...okay. I just want to sit a couple of seconds without having to say a word. Because if I start trying to say, "I'm sorry I caught you and Raymond fucking," I'll start laughing and when I laugh too hard, I get the hiccups and they can last for days.
answer: Don't get hiccups.

question: Isn't anything what it seems to be?...
answer: No...

question: Don't you think that's kind of lousy?
answer: Yes...

question: ...132 through 40 next? Sam should see this. I think I left in a line of his dialogue. Go ahead. Sweet Christ! I told 'em to hold that... Too late now...only make it worse. All right, save it. Nina. The shame of it...the shame! You've lost your son, your lover. You want to tear his throat out... but you stand meek...your guts burning with the shame of it.
answer: God, I don't know what's wrong with me.

question: Honey...you better know this...don't get all shook up now... Something got screwed up...the dailies...
answer: What?

question: Giddyap, soldier. Last one there's on Medicare.
answer: Where are we rushing to? I Was asleep...

question: Trouble staying awake, huh? Stick of gum? Makes you hum! Do you read?
answer: Short words.

question: Schickel and Bergenstadt... couple of Dutch comedy writers. See, it's got pictures. But don't skim. Chuck's gonna quiz you. If you pass, you get a free trip to Amsterdam and you can stick your finger in a dike.
answer: What the hell is this?

question: A pamphlet on how to get out of a sunken car. You know, they got this problem in Holland...those canals. So these guys are experts.
answer: Did Burt read this?

question: Something wrong? Why are you lagging?
answer: I'm trying to figure it out. That film. Where was I?

question: How tall is King Kong?
answer: Three-foot-six.

question: Good boy. I got all kinds of versions. Wanna go back and see some? I've even got a version where you fly the helicopter and I'm driving the Duesenberg. It's a dilly. 166A They have now charged out of the building and are racing across the grounds toward the set.
answer: What about the version where I go over the bridge and die in the water?

question: Hey, kid, what is this with you? That red dye must be eating through your scalp and affecting your brain. Why would I want to hurt you?
answer: Because you don't like my tatoo.

question: I think it's beautiful. It's heroic! I think it's a major work that may rank with the Edsel grill! Now goddamnit, I gotta go back and do my picture! Will you take this thing and read?!
answer: I knew a guy...who stepped on a bouncing Betty booby trap. Stepping on it wasn't his problem...they explode when you step off. So all ...He had this screwy West Texas accent, I remember, "Hey fellas...hey fellas..."

question: Why don't you let the kid go before he gets hurt?
answer: Chuck keeps an eye on him.

question: He's dangerous to have around. Stop playing games, Eli. Tell Jake you've replaced him. What are you so hooked on?
answer: He helps me understand the kid in our story.

question: Bullshit.
answer: He's like one of those land mines left over from a war, that go off from time to time. You read about it in the paper two or three years later...some kid in a bell tower shoots a dozen students for no reason at all...his mother says he was always such a good boy...I guess I'd like to know what he really did.

question: ...It was so unnecessary...For Christ's sake, I'm no shrinking violet...I've had my ass pinched black and blue by account execs for not showing enough enthusiasm for Vitalis. But this from Eli...it was so pointless...sadistic...
answer: ..."Open All windows slowly to keep pressure from caving in the roof, should an unexpected skid achieve aquatic consequences..." That's kind of witty. Beautiful...There's a second school of thought that says the first school is all wet. It says, "Keep the windows rolled up tight and wait for the air bubble."

question: Say it was an accident...benefit of the doubt. But then to use me that way...like a gadget...Why would Eli do that? He's not a cruel man...
answer: He's not a cruel man. He's a crazy man. A maniac.

question: What?
answer: "The water pressure at two hundred feet can crush a man into the size of an egg." He wants to get that on film....so he's gonna kill me.

question: What in God's name are you babbling about?!
answer: It's a rotten shame about your folks and your naked ass, but dying always scared me a little, okay? Did you know that Eli almost strangled a man because he stopped the camera when Burt got killed?!

question: What is going on in that head of yours?! You take the word of some...malcontent...technician!
answer: ...I saw the bruises!

question: ...And I saw Eli that night when he had to tell Burt's brother on the phone...I saw the tears.
answer: She saw the tears! Did you ask him what he was crying about?! 'Cause you can bet your sweet tits, it wasn't over Burt. He was crying over losing his fucking shot!

question: Didn't they give I.Q. tests in the army? What did you get...minus twelve? Haven't you figured out yet why he's working himself to death? What his film is all about? He's trying to tell people not to kill each other!
answer: And you know what? You want the shock of your life...? I understand what the son-of-a-bitch is saying, and he may be right...which makes me what? Minus twelve, the dumb schmuck with a gun. That doesn't change the fact that he's crazy. If he had his way, there wouldn't be a soldier left alive by morning. But

question: Stop it...sweetheart...I'd die if anything happened to you. It's my father...I won't talk to him...You're all driving me crazy...I won't talk to him.!
answer: Hi...hello?

question: Tell them I'm not here. Tell them anything. Tell them I'm working.
answer: Okay, Chuck. I'll meet you in an hour. For me. Amazing how they keep secrets around here. What if I told you I wasn't going to do the stunt?

question: I'd say fine.
answer: And what if I told you I was gonna get out of here tonight...and that I want you to come with me?

question: But there's just one more day of shooting...
answer: What if I can't wait?

question: I...I have two more scenes...
answer: That's a shame.

question: Look at this mother...I'll bet these guys could build an Arabian out of a jackass.
answer: Why not? You built a stunt man out of one.

question: Stunt man? Three days and you've already grown those big brass balls? Jump up and down and let me hear 'em clang, and then do me a favor and leave 'em home for this gag. There's just enough room in that Duesenberg for a normal guy...who thinks! Show me how long you can hold your breath. Now, look around. Whaddya see?...No roll bar in the roof. That's because the roof caving in really looks gassy on film. You got your protection in the back of the seat...steel sheeting. If the roof goes too far, you get your goddamn head down quick! You listening to me?!...Nod Your head. You got good lungs. You got no shoulder harness because it would show on camera. So when you hit the water, you brace yourself against the steering wheel. It's reinforced. You couldn't break it loose with dynamite...you gettin' light-headed yet? Keep your hands off the doors... You're leaving through the window. You lower them slowly as you sink to equalize the pressure. What are you waitin' for? I'm not gonna be down there holding your hand. Slower. When you hit bottom, the windows are open and you're gonna make like a minnow. But first, a little fresh air wouldn't hurt. You reach down under the seat and, what do you know, a respirator...Make like you're reaching for it. There'll be one there tomorrow. No, keep your face forward, the camera is behind you and it's still running. You feel like your lungs are gonna burst? Good. That's the way you're supposed to act like you feel. The moment that water gets above your nose, you gotta look like you're drowning. Remember? Burt wasn't so good at that.
answer: He sure as hell convinced me.

question: Things happen crossin' the street! If somethin' goes cockeyed...screw the scene! Get that mask on. There's enough oxygen to get you to China. We'll try it again.
answer: Let me catch my breath.

question: What you'll catch is a lungful of water! You're at the bottom of the river!...You breathe when I goddamn tell you to breathe!
answer: Hey, Chuck, you blind?...Can't you see I've got my respirator on?

question: You just goddamn remember you don't have gills!! What?!! Eli's at the police station!
answer: That's the best news I've heard. Let's hope it's a felony.

question: He needs Gabe. They're lookin' for a driver so I'm gonna take him. Come on with me.
answer: For what?

question: You and me are gonna talk about windows and oxygen and seat belts and things like that. And if you're a good boy and listen and don't be a smart ass, maybe I'll let you sit in the back seat with Nina Franklin.
answer: Nina?

question: Gabe, Nina... You two better wait here.
answer: I hate this, damn it! Couldn't you have done it without me?

question: Let's say you owe it to him. Until two or three days ago, I had a pretty good actor on my hands. Next time you take out the clippers, be a little humane, make sure the guy's got one to spare.
answer: What did you want me to do? Take him in the back room and unzip his fly every time he fluffed a line? What else can I do for your film?

question: Oh, Jake! Come on! You wouldn't know your anal invert from a hole in the ground. Raymond makes bad jokes, but they're not illegal. Christ, you've seen us all on the set...clowning around. My company's been pouring sixty thousand dollars a week into this place, for which your mayor and governor seem very grateful! We paid enough in taxes and fees alone to buy you parking meters from here to the boardwalk! Jake, I got a very horny leading lady who's got an early call and would like to spend some time with her boyfriend before she makes "night-night." Now, can I please get 'em outta here before they really do something illegal...and in front of witnesses! Sorry I had to put you through that. I know it was humiliating.
answer: ...It was awful...I hated it. But you did save that man's life.

question: Yeah, that was really nice of me. I'm a nice person. I just wish I had the strength to go to his room and break his spine. On the last day of filming the queen decides to come out of the closet! Wouldn't that have made a lovely headline? You understand, of course, that the film would've been destroyed. Doing that to me...
answer: Eli, what's wrong?

question: Nothing serious. Just a little self-indulgence. Feel-sorry-for- Eli-time. I'm sorry, but you know...it's too goddamn much. Why's everybody on my back? When's somebody gonna say, "There, there Eli?" I'm really surrounded by friends, allies and you..."What else can I do for your film, Eli?"
answer: That's not fair.

question: What's not fair...getting my feelings "hurt?" When did I lose you to that soldier boy, Nina? That nice, wholesome, swell-looking kid...wanted by every cop, the FBI and God knows who else, for God knows what crime. Come on, Nina, those blue eyes have bedazzled our little girl. For Christ's sake, he reeks of blood.
answer: You sound as crazy as...

question: As who?
answer: He thinks you're trying to... ...harm him.

question: How'd you know I was down here?
answer: The desk clerk...

question: How about that for luck? Burt's from Idaho...no picture on the driver's license.
answer: Who are you?

question: Name it... Hey, how's this? A World War One, uh...what did they call 'em?... dogfaces... somethin'... doughboys. Wanna be the nurse? 179A From some hospital props, he grabs a wheelchair and shoves it toward her. ...You tell me this wouldn't work? A pretty nurse pushing a vet in a wheelchair? When we hit that roadblock, we'd have 'em crying like babies.
answer: Who the hell are you?

question: Somebody trying to stay alive...anybody--that can get past the dogs and the quicksand... Who did Eli say I was?
answer: I'm asking you, God damn...

question: Easy with that tatoo...it mighta lost me Eli, but it won me Lt. Emily Schmidt, the greatest boobs in Southeast Asia...and a very patriotic chick. So I got this tattoo, for 28 bucks. And when she saw this shoulder, let me tell ya, holy Jesus! Following which I got the clap from the Lt. And hepatitis from the tattoo needle. You know what bothers me? I think Emily is gonna be very offended by Eli's picture.
answer: Why do they want you? What did you do?

question: Eli'd tell you...I was a soldier. I did the same as everybody, just one of the boys... emptied my M-16 at any sound... don't know whether I killed gooks or cherries...the new kids from the States, we call 'em cherries, which they were for maybe fifteen minutes. The dry season is when it really breaks loose. You get very tired. It's like falling asleep at the wheel. You close your eyes and it still goes on. You're killin' them, they're killin' you. Couldn't tell ya now what was real except I'm here. Hey, once when things were rough and the grass ran out, I shot the hell out of a water buffalo. Actually, I wasn't a bad soldier...better than most. Got lotsa pretty ribbons. Funny...sort of like when I did that first stunt and everybody started clapping... nothing like a slap on the back to ruin a man, blow his sense of proportion. So, I got home...and, uh...I guess I expected something. Nothing fancy, but... something, you know...a free car wash, double blue chip stamps, extra time on the parking meter... I don't know... Instead, people... uh, didn't seem too pleased. In fact, they acted like I was gonna start killing babies... Shit. I was supposed to get married, run an ice cream parlor. I gotta go.
answer: ...What about the roadblocks?

question: I'll go through the woods.
answer: Don't you suppose there'll be cops in the woods.

question: I suppose there are cops in the woodwork! But what the hell...it's a nice night.
answer: I've always liked the woods at night. They're very romantic... You can hunt for truffles. It might be such fun, we'd just keep going.

question: You said "we." What about your two scenes?
answer: That's true...One of them is three pages of me making a tunafish salad for an American flyer in 1917... And I've got to weigh that against losing the man I love. It's a big decision.

question: Nina, you're making me crazy.
answer: I'm sorry. I'm a little crazy myself. I can't let you go and I don't even know who you are. Why are they chasing you?! What have you done? What happens to me in the woods? Will I need a bayonet too? 179C He stands there, staring at her, his face suddenly savage. After everything, the lady is afraid of him. He picks up the duffel bag and moves for the door, then turns on her, punishing her with his words.

question: The charge was attempted murder. I bashed this cop's head in. It took the jury about two fucking minutes. It could of been worse. It could of been life. But the judge...he looked real nice at me, and said you were a damn good soldier, son...So he only gave me twenty years. No way! Enough!...You know how long I was in that prison -- nineteen months -- and then I was gone! I was gone! Caught me breaking into a store...oh, not to rob it...I went there to kill the bastard who owned it...
answer: Why?

question: ...Because... 179D Suddenly the ice turns to steam. His self-control shatters like glass. There in the basement of a 100-year old hotel, before an audience of one, Cameron ERUPTS, spewing out the memory of his mortification and crucifixion...not without the silent resignation of Jesus, but with the howling rage of a mad dog...Pluto with the rabies... ...Because...it seemed like a good idea to twist his fucking head off! Said I could be his partner when I got back...lyin' son of a bitch was "real sorry things were slack..." Slack my ass...he just didn't want me hangin' around because he was bangin' my old lady. So I go down and start bangin' on his door! ...He's closed. It's two o'clock in the morning. I want to smash his face in and he's closed! "OPEN UP, YOU BASTARD."
answer: Your hand!

question: Bang! That bright, shiny front window went bye-bye! ...Maybe he's screwin' her behind the counter...I climb in there screamin' "WHERE ARE YA? Come out here and be a man! Where are ya? Behind that counter, you son-of-a- bitch?" Ya know what's behind that counter?... ...And these little Mickey Mouse faces on the walls!...with candy eyeballs!... I smashed that fucking fudge pot across the room, smack into that shelf full of animals...and it starts raining pussycats and monkeys and kangaroo cookies like Noah's Ark! "How long should a girl wait" she says? FOR GODDAMN EVER, BITCH, THAT'S HOW LONG! I picked up this fifty-pound ice cream vat...FLAVOR-OF-THE-MONTH!... ROYAL-BAVARIAN-CHOCOLATE-MIST!...and I started running with that son-of- a-bitch... It's not funny!
answer: Oh, baby... Let me go to the bathroom. I'm gonna have an accident.

question: You'll miss the main part! Killer Cameron's ghastly crime! I was freaked out of my head! And, suddenly there's this big flashlight shining in my face. I just grabbed that goddamn ice cream bucket and slopped it...right over the guy's head! It's not funny. It wasn't him. It was a cop. I got out of there like a shot. I didn't know he was knocked out. How the hell did I know he was gonna lay there all night with his head in the ice cream?
answer: Oh, my God. He died?

question: No, he's in the hospital.
answer: Oh, no.

question: Oh, yes. That ice cream's goddamn cold! His nose...it froze and his ear froze, see...and... No, it's terrible!...He lost the tip of his nose and his ear lobe... I'll tell ya, it's a bad year to mess with cops. You get the FBI screaming down on your ass...
answer: Oh, God. Too late...Thanks a lot!

question: Can't...not 'til seven o'clock. Mr. Cross's orders.
answer: I'm sure Mr. Cross will understand when you tell him that Miss Franklin had a sudden desire for Swedish pancakes for breakfast and this gentleman had a sudden desire to keep me company...I'm Nina Franklin, the star of the film.

question: Pancake house don't open 'til eight.
answer: That's all right, we'll find some place.

question: Town's closed up pretty tight this time of night.
answer: Then we'll drive to Cape Long.

question: I can't believe it...He knows. The son-of-a-bitch knows whatever I'm thinking. I'm beginning to feel like something that Sam wrote! I'm not real. I'm some jerk American flyer from World War I who has to go over a bridge and die because the goddamn script says so! It's crazy...I'm trapped in his goddamn story. If somebody lost that page, I'd be fine. If he crossed it out and wrote something else like -- "At the last moment, he veers the big car from the railing--then goes speeding on to live happy ever after..." ...How about that?! Empty road, me out there all alone, the crew 'way back, breathless as I approach the bridge. And then..."Hey, what happened?!" A fucking rewrite's what happened! I'll have a fifteen- minute jump on them before they figure out they're shooting a new version!
answer: ...And what about the love story? What happens to the Austrian girl? People will leave the movie feeling terrible...I know! She goes with him!

question: How?
answer: In here. No...look... See how big it is? Comfortable, too...Honestly, honey, it's a better ending.

question: Nina, get out of the trunk.
answer: And what happens in the morning? Do I show up on the set in my little pink pinafore and say, "Hi, Eli. Where's my hug and kiss...?" How do I do that now?

question: ...Get out of the trunk.
answer: ...Or should I trot up to my room to catch a couple of winks and cuddle up with a dozen sleeping pills?

question: It's my nightmare...Stay out! This isn't the time to solve your neurotic problems! I'm trying to stay alive!
answer: So am I. And I never claimed not to have "neurotic problems!"

question: I can't come any further. What should I do? I'll get the dress all muddy and I need it for the next scene.
answer: Tunafish salad...I know.

question: They found me five minutes after you left. I felt ridiculous.
answer: Just as well!

question: "How!" I have always had a great compassion for your people. Long before it was popular, I felt a repugnance for General Custer. My God, I think he's breathing. There're days I can't do anything right. I hope this doesn't screw up our relationship, your being alive and all.
answer: ...You sure took a hell of a chance, Eli...why didn't you just let me go last night?

question: What, with Nina in the trunk? I've got scenes to shoot with her...
answer: ...All right. This morning then. Chuck could have done the stunt.

question: I knew a guy who made an anti-war film. When they previewed it in his hometown, army enlistment went up six hundred percent. I'm making this film trying to convince the whole world that maybe there's a better way to get home for Thanksgiving...and I can't even convince one dumb kid with a tattoo...I couldn't have you run around paranoid the rest of your life thinking I was trying to kill you.
answer: Paranoid?

question: Hey Sam, the kid just licked your screenplay. He named the disease.
answer: Yeah, what?

question: ...a social disease, very common.
answer: ...like gonorrhea...

question: ...What thousand bucks? That stunt paid six-fifty.
answer: Chuck told me a thousand... A thousand!

question: Okay, seven-fifty. Split the difference...
answer: Bullshit! You're trying to screw me!!

question: Christ! You're doing it again! Sam! This paranoid little bastard still doesn't understand your damn screenplay!
answer: That's your big problem, Eli! You use people! I want my money, a thousand bucks!

question: Six-fifty!! Rewrite the battle scene and let the tank run him over! The stunt pays six-fifty!
answer: Come back here. I'm tired of being your goddamn clown! Pay me my thousand bucks!
